highlighted_context: As part of our new GCSE Mathematics and Numeracy, we are looking for suggestions for new contexts that can be **utilised** within our assessments.
reasoning: 'Used' is a simpler and generally preferred alternative to 'utilised' in formal writing.

highlighted_context: Materials from all of the professional learning events that have taken place this academic year for GCSE Mathematics and GCSE **Mathematics-Numeracy** are available on [WJEC Portal](https://portal.wjec.co.uk/) (the WJEC secure website).
reasoning: The qualification name is inconsistently hyphenated here ('Mathematics-Numeracy') compared to the en-dash usage ('Mathematics – Numeracy') elsewhere in the document.

highlighted_context: The materials can be accessed by first selecting 'Resources', then 'Subject-Specific Support Materials **inc** CPD & Exemplars'.
reasoning: In formal documents, 'including' or 'incl.' is preferred over the abbreviation 'inc'.

highlighted_context: The materials can be accessed by first selecting 'Resources', then 'Subject-Specific Support Materials inc CPD **&** Exemplars'.
reasoning: In formal writing, 'and' is generally preferred over the ampersand symbol (&) unless it is part of a proper name or specific abbreviation.

highlighted_context: They can be found under the Key Documents tab on the GCSE Mathematics web page: [GCSE Mathematics and GCSE **Mathematics - Numeracy** Key Documents](https://www.wjec.co.uk/qualifications/mathematics-gcse/#tab_keydocuments) [(wjec.co.uk)](https://www.wjec.co.uk/qualifications/mathematics-gcse/#tab_keydocuments)
reasoning: The qualification name uses a hyphen in the link text, which is inconsistent with the en-dash usage ('Mathematics – Numeracy') in the preceding sentence and elsewhere in the document.

highlighted_context: Blended learning packages, **exam walkthroughs** and knowledge organisers are available for GCSE Mathematics and GCSE Mathematics – Numeracy, as well as for the new Made-for-Wales GCSE in Mathematics and Numeracy (Double Award).
reasoning: 'Walkthroughs' should be written as one word or hyphenated ('walk-throughs') in British English.
